stem: A 29-year-old pregnant client with HELLP syndrome is being monitored in the L&D high-acuity unit. Based on the documentation in the OB-Hepatic Lab & Imaging Log, which finding is the most concerning indicator of a potentially fatal complication?

tabs.title: RUQ Ultrasound (Portable)
tabs.content: Impression: Subcapsular hepatic hematoma measuring 8 cm in the right lobe of the liver. The liver capsule appears distended but intact. No free peritoneal fluid noted at this time.

tabs.title: Nursing Assessment
tabs.content: Current: Client reports sudden, 'tearing' pain in the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) that radiates to the right shoulder. Blood pressure has dropped from 158/94 to 92/58 in the last 15 minutes.

options.text: The 8 cm subcapsular hepatic hematoma and sudden drop in blood pressure
The AST of 680 indicating liver cell death

rationale.correct: While all HELLP findings are serious, the **subcapsular hepatic hematoma combined with the drop in blood pressure (a1)** indicates an impending or active hepatic rupture. In HELLP syndrome, liver swelling can cause a bleed 'under the skin' (capsule) of the liver. If the capsule tears or ruptures, the client will experience rapid exsanguination (internal bleeding) and death. 'Shoulder pain' (Kehr's sign) in an OB patient with RUQ pain and shock is a classic indicator of blood in the peritoneum.
clinicalPearls: HELLP = Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets.
Hepatic rupture is the 'Silent Killer' of HELLP patients. Mortality is > 50%.
Priority action: Massive transfusion and emergent surgery (Laparotomy).

questionTrap.trap: Choosing the Platelets (a2) because the number is low.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Platelets are a part of the diagnostic *definition* of HELLP, but the hematoma/rupture is the *complication* that kills the patient in minutes. Always prioritize 'The Rupture' over 'The Lab.'

mnemonic.title: HELLP-Pop
mnemonic.expansion: Liver swells, then it pops. Ruptured liver, pressure drops.
